message: @rkarwa We need a "github" for users.
@doolin you can set a wiki to readonly, so that users cant edit it
and actually sometimes 'brew install' is the instructions for things non-developers need
any high-profile or popular project could benefit from a domain. Homebrew is popular enough to qualify
but I only ever do tools for developer type projects

cause I wanted to get people using hub
github pages are fine, not enough projects bother to set them up, I bet he would argue
http://mxcl.github.com/homebrew/ is a great example of a home page hosted on github
all it really needs is its own domain

@timocratic yep, like that page for homebrew saves me a lot more time compared to projects that just have a readme at the bottom that's full of text that doesn't get me anywhere, with install directions or what have you hidden somewhere in the middle
It wouldn't be so strange if it didn't require a big incantation to setup
@icco indeed! is there an equivalent for your os of choice?
@timocratic I'm going to try the github wiki next, but will be writing the content myself.
it shows you take your project seriously.

you crazy kids and your open source projects...

@adelcambre that's the last straw, I'm installing soloist and chef'ing that up

Well there's apt. But what hub/rvm/gist does is best: curl http://defunkt.io/hub/standalone -sLo ~/bin/hub
arguably homebrew is not something that'd be used by someone that would be uncomfortable with github. but i really like that that page tells me upfront about how to get started.
ack

He didn't mention, we do have a project page generator.  It's basic, but it should at least give you a good start on a basic user-facing page
@eridius I use a simple test: if the project could turn into a product, I consider setting up it's own domain.
I totally love ack
mislav yeah, the general github pages would work fine for most projects, but more projects could stand to use them

cool, tnx!
lot of people say every project needs a domain. it does not. github wiki or github pages as main page to send users to is just fine for most.
just go into your repo admin and turn on Pages, it'll offer to generate one
you would, tammer
beware nerd wrath
@mislav and yet you made that awesome hub page
anyone here not using hub? stop what you're doing http://defunkt.io/hub/
Wait, can someone explain to me why I shouldn't be developing on master?
@defunkt Oh cool. I had never seen ack before today. I may have to switch.
On solo things and pre 1.0 things, the only branch is master, and sometimes refactor.
hahah

@jacobian long-running development in master makes it harder for collaborators to grab the latest source and start work. Instead they have to back up a few changesets and start from there. Git is awesomely complex and its really easy to do something wrong if you're inexperienced.
@timocratic It's useful to push WIP commits (you are creating WIP commits, right?). You wouldn't want those on master
no more, no less
s/and/on/
but those are surprisingly rare
@jacobian I don't see it as a hard and fast thing, but on bigger projects i use git-flow, and so master only has releases.
@timocratic it's a matter of scale and discipline. Eventually something gets through and that can back up your whole process for hours.
@jacobian you can if you want.
rebase == SATAN
s/EHAD/HEAD/
@nuclearsandwich you will never know if devs use rebase on their local flow, though
@eridius and @steveklabnik I'm open to having my mind changed but I need good reasons.
@nuclearsandwich sadly, for me at least Git is complex experience or no. I'm two years and a bit into using Git and it still makes me feel like a n00b at least once a week.
I think the pow pipe to sh is sexy
It spans multiple files but builds into a single standalone
indeed
@mislav My hope is that by using a better home page, more projects can become high-profile popular.
@nuclearsandwich only if you push shite?  As long as you develop and master, and keep CI green your fine. ;)
@jacobian The reason I try to encourage not developing in master at work is because it discourages concurrent development on separate features.
@nuclearsandwich That's a stupendously good reason.
it needs to have lots of inside joke features too
You're Doing It Wrong™
@timocratic I love pointing them to gitref.org
second order of business, wire up irc bot to CI i hope
@timocratic: I understand that they blur, but yet, discrete documented releases are important to your users.

@timocratic that's fine if you're solo, but when developing in a group/community, you should develop on feature branches... for your own sanity. That doesn't mean you ever have to push those feature branches
I absolutely love being able to say `git log --first-parent` and seeing all the merges that tell me what they did really quickly without having to see a dozen commits
@timocratic I completely disagree. WIP is useful. Small, frequent commits
@timocratic I use WIP when I need to go work on something else and don't think I have a single logical commit right now. I don't usually push them though
history should not be mutable. We don't have time machines.
I see why the kernel uses it, I'd never allow it in my devel process.
@jacobian ah yeah, it's definitely the C/assembly of source management :/
it sucks that people yell at anyone over something so silly
everything is trade-offs, and branches have a cost
I'd argue actually WIP is a sign of *lack* of discipline :D
s/your/you're/ *facepalm*
even when working on solo projects, I tend to use branches for features
rebase is a powerful and dangerous tool
:D
@defunkt precisely, everyone on my team is a git newbie (even me, I prefer hg)
we're talking about nerds, right?
git is painful enough to learn for new users without the assholes
at GitHub, we keep merge commits because they contain useful data

no no no no no.

@listrophy those aren't WIP

which was kinda hilarious

@petdance if you do continuos release those barriers blur
@timocratic if anyone at work does it, I hit them with a stick.
I prefer @steveklabnik's analogy to @eridius's
Give me a situation in git where rebase is appropriate on a four man team.
git is hard because it's easy. it's like c, or assembly. it's low level, doesn't do much, but it means it can be iffy to reason about sometimes.
@timocratic me too. More fun that way.

@timocratic not really - I barely use rebase. Stuff like when to -ff and when not, when to branch and when not, what gets pushed where, how tracking works, ... Git regularly makes me feel confused and stupid.
i mean that's just Best Practices
yeah, I mean that man is a (unpaid) profession troll :D
see reddit vs hackernews
rebase -i --autosquash EHAD~%
for instance
I feel about Git the same way I feel about my chainsaw. I love them, and feel like a badass using them, but I'm always scared I'm going to hurt myself.
so I always giggle when I use it
I guess it's more "best practices" than day-to-day usage that escape me. I just feel like I'm perpetually DOIN IT RONG.
@jacobian you should just say "The github guys said I can do it this way" whichever way you decide (rebase or not).  I think they'll back that up, right @technoweenie?
@jacobian It definitely is. Git supports practically any workflow under the sun. Projects should be defining their workflow just like they define their code style
@timocratic we haven't rolled CI yet. I'm p/t right now and in school. Going f/t in Summer. First order of business set up CI and server management. (now manual)
i think there's a big difference between the web and desktop apps
@thedaniel IRC and notifo, yeah.
any time I have a series of commits that should be conceptually grouped together, I consider using a branch
exactly
I started with a flame, but really reasonably, rebase is dangerous for small things.
rvm is great at constantly releasing changes
it works fine for unpushed stuff ;)
it's better to provide a clear history than an accurate history.
rebase is horrible for newbies. It should require a breathalyzer and git certification
yeah, my biggest problem with reflog is in my head it's pronounced re-flog
git's the worst dvcs except for all the others

@technoweenie but see that's kinda what I'm talking about. When I started using Git, one of the arguments about why I should use it was that it has rebase. Then a few months later a kernel hacker told me that rebase was evil and I stopped using it. Then I got yelled at a few months later for not using pull --rebase. THen a few months after *that* I got yelled at *for* using pull --rebase.
@jacobian that's what happens when we let kernel hackers create user experiences

@listrophy I was being a little tongue in cheek, but I have an honest question - as long as you keep master shippable, do you really need a bunch of branches?
perhaps it should be a function of # of devs/concurrent features being developed (aka project size)?
I use branches very selectively. If it's a big overhaul that can't be pushed out in stages, for example

as long as the commits arent published, rebase away
